Package ru.golubev.openweathersdk.internal

Class OpenWeatherApi

  • java.lang.Object
    • ru.golubev.openweathersdk.internal.OpenWeatherApi
  • public final class OpenWeatherApi
extends java.lang.Object
    Main client for interacting with the OpenWeather API.

    This class provides both synchronous and asynchronous methods to retrieve current weather data from the OpenWeather API. It handles HTTP communication, response parsing, error handling, and resource management.

    Key features:

    • Synchronous and asynchronous weather data retrieval
    • Multi-language support for weather descriptions
    • Multiple unit systems (metric/imperial)
    • Comprehensive error handling and exception mapping
    • Configurable HTTP client (shared or dedicated)
    • Graceful shutdown and resource cleanup
    • Extensive logging capabilities

    Thread Safety: This class is thread-safe and can be used concurrently from multiple threads. The AtomicBoolean ensures safe shutdown state management.

    Example usage:

    
 // Synchronous call
 WeatherResponse weather = api.weather("London", SupportedLanguage.ENGLISH, Units.METRIC);

 // Asynchronous call
 CompletableFuture<WeatherResponse> future = api.weatherAsync("Paris", SupportedLanguage.FRENCH, Units.METRIC);
 future.thenAccept(response -> {
     System.out.println("Temperature: " + response.getTemperature().getTemp());
 });

 // Shutdown when done
 api.shutdown();
    Since:
    1.0
    See Also:
    WeatherResponse, SupportedLanguage, Units, OpenWeatherApiClientException

    • Method Detail

      • weather

        public WeatherResponse weather​(java.lang.String city,
                               SupportedLanguage lang,
                               Units unit)
        Retrieves current weather data synchronously for the specified city.

        This method blocks until the API response is received and processed. Use for simple applications or when asynchronous processing is not required.

        Parameters:
        city - the city name for which to retrieve weather data; must not be null or empty
        lang - the language for weather descriptions; must not be null
        unit - the measurement system for weather data; must not be null
        Returns:
        WeatherResponse containing comprehensive weather information
        Throws:
        ShutdownException - if the API instance has been shut down
        RequestCancellationException - if the HTTP request was cancelled
        OpenWeatherApiClientException - for network or IO-related errors
        WeatherApiException - for API-level errors (invalid API key, city not found, etc.)
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - for response parsing failures

        Example:

        
 try {
     WeatherResponse response = api.weather("London", SupportedLanguage.ENGLISH, Units.METRIC);
     System.out.println("Temperature: " + response.getTemperature().getTemp());
 } catch (WeatherApiException e) {
     System.out.println("API error: " + e.getMessage());
 } catch (OpenWeatherApiClientException e) {
     System.out.println("Network error: " + e.getMessage());
 }
        See Also:
        WeatherResponse, SupportedLanguage, Units

      • weatherAsync

        public java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture<WeatherResponse> weatherAsync​(java.lang.String city,
                                                                            SupportedLanguage lang,
                                                                            Units unit)
        Retrieves current weather data asynchronously for the specified city.

        This method returns immediately with a CompletableFuture that will be completed when the API response is available. Suitable for non-blocking applications and reactive programming patterns.

        Parameters:
        city - the city name for which to retrieve weather data; must not be null or empty
        lang - the language for weather descriptions; must not be null
        unit - the measurement system for weather data; must not be null
        Returns:
        CompletableFuture that will be completed with the WeatherResponse or completed exceptionally with an appropriate exception
        Throws:
        ShutdownException - if the API instance has been shut down

        Example:

        
 CompletableFuture<WeatherResponse> future = api.weatherAsync(
     "Tokyo", SupportedLanguage.JAPANESE, Units.METRIC);

 future.thenApply(response -> {
     System.out.println("Temperature: " + response.getTemperature().getTemp());
     return response;
 }).exceptionally(throwable -> {
     if (throwable instanceof WeatherApiException) {
         System.out.println("API error: " + throwable.getMessage());
     } else if (throwable instanceof OpenWeatherApiClientException) {
         System.out.println("Network error: " + throwable.getMessage());
     }
     return null;
 });
        See Also:
        CompletableFuture, FutureWrapper

      • shutdown

        public void shutdown()
        Shuts down the API instance and releases resources.

        After shutdown, all subsequent method calls will throw ShutdownException. If using a shared HTTP client, only the API instance is shut down, not the client. If using a dedicated client, the HTTP client is properly shutdown.

        Note: This method is idempotent - calling it multiple times has no additional effect after the first successful call.

        Example:

        
 try {
     // Use API...
 } finally {
     api.shutdown();
 }
        See Also:
        HttpClientShutdown
